title: Kurt Suzuki has MRI on hip flexor, still uncertain for Game 5
text:
Washington Nationals catcher Kurt Suzuki had an MRI Saturday on his right hip flexor, which he injured in Game 3 of the World Series the night before, and his availability for Sunday’s Game 5 is still unknown.

Suzuki hurt the muscle when blocking a pitch in the dirt Friday. He finished that half-inning but then decided he couldn’t continue at his best, and Yan Gomes replaced him for the rest of the game.

When manager Dave Martinez met with the media Saturday before Game 4, he said the results of the MRI hadn’t come back yet. But he wants to know before the day is out what his catcher situation is.

“I want a definitive today. I mean, we have to,” Martinez said. “If we deem that he can’t be ready for a couple days then we’re gonna have to do something … Last night, I spoke to him. He doesn’t feel as bad as he did yesterday, so that’s a good sign. Till I actually hear from the doctor and Paul and see what the results were, I can’t say at this point how long he’s gonna be out.”

In the worst-case scenario, Suzuki would be out a few days, and Raudy Read would be the most likely replacement for him on the 25-man roster.

Gomes will start behind the plate for Game 4 and bat eighth in the order. Gomes is the usual batterymate for starter Patrick Corbin, so he was likely going to play Saturday even if Suzuki wasn’t hurt.

But Suzuki usually catches Max Scherzer, who will start Game 5.

“We’ve worked really well together,” Scherzer said. “Just being in sync at what pitch to throw and even in big situations. But I’ve also worked with Yan this year several times … We do have a good rapport with each other. We do understand what’s going on, and Yan’s very astute to the game of being able to watch what’s gong on and how I see those guys and what we want to do.”
